With a rich history and a commitment to excellence, this esteemed funeral home has earned a reputation for providing compassionate and personalized services to those who have lost a loved one.

A Tradition of Excellence

The funeral home's experienced team is comprised of licensed professionals who are dedicated to ensuring that every family receives the highest level of attention and compassion during their time of need. From the initial consultation to the final farewell, the staff at Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home is committed to providing a seamless and dignified experience.

H B Jones - January 05, 1928 - May 04, 2024

Departed: 05/04/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: H.B. Jones passed away on Saturday, May 4, 2024 following a car accident. HB was born in Hughes County, Oklahoma, on January 5th, 1928, son of Hester B. and Nannie Mae (Tiller) Jones. He grew up and lived around Calvin, Oklahoma.HB was a World War II veteran, serving proudly in the US Navy.HB was a farmer and an avid fisherman. He had been collecting arrowheads since he was a small child, all picked up in the woods, fields, and creek banks around Calvin, where he spent his life.He was kind, loved his family fiercely, was proud of his independence, and he had a dry sense of humor that sometimes required you to pause before you realized he was being funny.He was 96, lived alone, and his accident was in his beloved black Mustang. He would have wanted it that way.He was preceded in death by his parents, his sister Imogene (Gene) Jones Rose and his brother Jimmie Jones.He is survived by 6 nieces and nephews. Mona Orvig; Jana Powell and husband, Sam; Regina Morris and husband, Kevin; Boyd Jones and wife, Heather; Jason Jones and wife, Ashley; and Christina Dockrey and husband Michael. He is also survived by his sister-in-law, Orvetta Jones, great-nieces and nephews, cousins, and local friends.Per his wishes, no services will be held.Cremation service under the direction of Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home.

Virginia Lee Smith - February 14, 1948 - May 03, 2024

Departed: 05/03/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: Virginia Lee Smith passed away Friday, May 3, 2024 in Edmond, Oklahoma at the age of 76. Virginia was born on February 14, 1948 in Holdenville, Oklahoma to Mr. Hubert Patrick and Georgia (Venable) Byerly. Virginia graduated from Holdenville High School Class of 1966. Virginia was the secretary for Holdenville High School for many years. She was also a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) Women's Auxiliary. Above all, she loved taking care of many by being a Mom, Nanny, second mom, and friend. Virginia is preceded in death by her parents, husband Gene Smith, and her son Stephen Hickerson. She is survived by her son Jeffery Hickerson and wife Sunday of Edmond, 8 grandchildren, 4 great grandchildren, siblings: Alton Byerly, Bryan Byerly, and Jane Lumpkin. Virginia is also survived by numerous other relatives and friends. Viewing will be 9am to 7pm, Monday, May 6, 2024 at Hudson-Phillips Funeral HomeFuneral service will be 2 pm Tuesday May 7, 2024 at the Holdenville First Baptist Church with Pastor Dane Robinson officiating and burial to follow at Holdenville Cemetery under the direction of Hudson Phillips Funeral Home. Pallbearers are Ryan Hickerson, Colten Hickerson, Zach Hickerson, Jesse Davis, Austin Moffat and Ty Scott. Honorary Pallbearers are Barry Davis and Joey Mooers.

Sherry Gail Hinkle - December 21, 1961 - May 03, 2024

Departed: 05/03/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: Sherry Hinkle, 62, of Allen, Oklahoma went to be with her heavenly father on May 3, 2024 peacefully in her sleep. Sherry was born December 21st, 1961 in Fort Worth, TX to her parents Ramona Jo Cabral and Johnny M Cabral. Sherry was raised in Crowell, TX by her mother and her step dad Avis (Al) Sibert, where her parents ran a cafe and Sherry attended school. Sherry married Travis Hinkle in December of 1977 in Vernon, TX and later moved to Lamesa, TX where they raised their 4 children. She worked as a dietician and a home healthcare provider. Sherry enjoyed spending time with her family, playing cards, gambling and listening to classic country music. After the death of her husband Travis, Sherry moved to Allen Ok. Sherry worked and lived in Allen Ok until she met and fell in love with Frank Walters, who loved her and took care of her until her passing.Sherry was proceeded in death by her late husband Travis Glenn Hinkle, her mother Ramona Jo Sibert, her father Johnny M Cabral, her step dad Avis (Al) Sibert and her brother Gary Wayne Cabral.Survivors include her husband, Frank Walters of Allen, OK. Three daughters, Crystal Gail Hinkle of Ada, OK, Amanda Jo Bloxham and husband C.J. of Macomb, OK, and Angela Denise Witkowski and husband Larry of Big Spring, TX and one son Travis Earl Hinkle and wife Heather of Allen, OK. Sister, Belinda Tosh and husband Tommy of Apache, OK, sister Betty Carol Bordelon of Breckenridge, TX, sister Gloria Jean Buchanan and husband Bobby of Tow, TX , sister Ava Jo Peterson and husband Bill of South Bend, IN, brother Harold Wayne Sibert and wife Georgia of Amarillo, TX and brother Aaron Sibert of Apache Ok.Sherry has 8 grandchildren, 3 great grandchildren, and numerous other family members and friends.Pallbearers are Jim Wade, Steve Lewis, Kevin Spray, Leon Moore, Tony Johnson and Bill Spray.Viewing will be 1:00pm, Monday, May 6, 2024 at Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home.Funeral service will be10:00am, Tuesday, May 7, 2024 at Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home with Josh Moyer officiating.Texas graveside service will be 3:00pm, Wednesday, May 8, 2024 at Lamesa Memorial Park Cemetery, Lamesa, Texas with Pastor Jerry Walton officiating. Services under the direction of Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home, Holdenville, Oklahoma.

Sharon Kay Carpenter - March 11, 1945 - April 29, 2024

Departed: 04/29/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: Sharon Kay Carpenter, 79, of Holdenville, passed away April 29, 2024, in her home with loved ones. Sharon was a devoted wife, mother and teacher and a life-long member of the First Baptist Church of Holdenville. Sharon was born March 11, 1945, in Stamford, Texas, to Bob and Elvarie Stafford. She attended elementary school, junior high and high school in Holdenville. After graduation, Sharon studied at East Central State College, where she earned English and business certificates with highest honors.Sharon was wed to Tony Carpenter on July 1, 1966, at the First Baptist Church in Holdenville, and they had one son, John Carpenter of Oklahoma City. Sharon's 30-year teaching career began at South Side High School outside Altus and Wewoka High School. She then moved to Holdenville Public Schools, where she taught English at junior high and then at high school. Sharon was dedicated to her students and went above and beyond for them by working many early mornings, late nights and weekends. In addition to teaching, Sharon served as librarian at Holdenville Junior High and sponsor for the yearbook and honor society at Holdenville High School. She retired from teaching in 1999.Sharon was preceded in death by her parents, Robert Stafford and Elvarie Stafford. Sharon is survived by husband Tony, son John, sister Jane Standifird, life-long friend Judy Connally, many nephews and nieces, and other loved ones.Sharon touched many lives and will be profoundly missed. Pallbearers for Sharon's funeral service will be Ken Stark, Chris Carpenter, Trevor Carpenter, Trey Carpenter, Toby Carpenter, and Kyle Cates. Honorary pallbearers are brothers-in-law Mike Carpenter, Jim Carpenter, and Steve Carpenter as well as cousins James Stafford, John Stafford, and Ronnie Stafford.Viewing will be 3:00pm to 7:00pm, Thursday, May 2, 2024 at Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home.Funeral service will be 2:00pm, Friday, May 3, 2024 at the First Baptist Church of Holdenville with Pastor James Poulain officiating.Interment will follow at Holdenville Cemetery.Services are under the direction of Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home, Holdenville, Oklahoma.

Melba Charlene Dean - February 05, 1935 - April 22, 2024

Departed: 04/22/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: Melba Charlene Dean passed away Monday, April 22, 2024 at her home in Holdenville at the age of 89. Melba was born February 5th, 1935 at her home in Wetumka, Oklahoma to George and Gladys (Noe) Pruitt. She attended Elementary School at Friendship and High School at Yeager. Melba married the love of her life Paul Dean on November 12, 1955 at the Church of Christ in Holdenville, Oklahoma.Melba and Paul raised peanuts and cattle, where she was always by his side. They raised two girls and made their home in the Yeager area. She enjoyed sewing, gardening, fishing, camping and cooking for her family. Mostly she enjoyed her grandchildren and great-grandchildren.Melba is preceded in death by her parents George and Gladys Pruitt, twin brother Milburn (Cotton), brothers Wayne and George Lendon (Len) Pruitt and one great-grandson Justin Fitzpatrick. She is survived by husband Paul Dean of the home, two daughters Nancy Renfrow and husband John of Jenks, OK, Elizabeth (Beth) Dean of Holdenville, OK. Her five grandchildren Amberly Fitzpatrick and husband Cecil, April Walden and husband Shayne, Jason Refrow, Kyle Cates and wife Ashley, Christy Wilkes and husband Chris and one granddaughter of the heart Koral Linker and husband Kenny. Nine great-grandchildren Christopher Fitzpatrick, Conner and Madison Walden, Kaylee, Kenlee and Weston Wilkes, Kyler, Brody and Emma Cates and two of the heart Grayson and Kolter Linker. One sister Debra Moore of Wyomissing, PA., two sister-in-laws Marge Pruitt of Montrose, CO, and Margaret Jones of Ada, OK. Melba is survived by numerous other nieces, nephews, cousins, other relatives and friends.Pallbearers are Kyle Cates, Jason Renfrow, Shayne Walden, Chris Wilkes, Christopher Fitzpatrick and Conner Walden. Viewing will be 5:00pm to 7:00pm, Tuesday, April 23, 2024 at Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home, Holdenville.Funeral service will be 10:00am, Wednesday, April 24, 2024 at Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home Chapel with Pastor Tommy Azlin officiating.Interment will follow at Yeager Cemetery.Services are under the direction of Hudson-Phillips Funeral Home, Holdenville, Oklahoma

Sue attended Holdenville Public School. She married Charles Earl Moore on April 4, 1953 in Van Buren, Arkansas. Non was a cook at the Holdenville Public School for many years. She was owner of Sue's Snack Shack. Non was a member of Penn West Baptist Church and she was the oldest living church member. Non loved her family, cooking, baking, sewing and fishing. She also loved her time at Eufaula Lake, going to the river and the sand buggy. Non is preceded in death by her parents, husband Charles, daughter Debra Hull and 9 siblings. She is survived by her son Danny Moore of Holdenville, 5 grandchildren; Jennifer Roberts and husband Daniel, Leigh Ann Canfield and husband Justin, April Massad and husband Eric, Shan Moore, Allyson Burden, great grandchildren; Brittain Valdez, Hannah North, Marcie Carolina, Faith Dockery, Micah Dockery, Brodey Massad, Roman Burden, Evertt Burden, 9 great great grandchildren and sibling Eldon Brittain and wife Lorrie of Holdenville. Florence Ann Keathley - May 07, 1942 - April 14, 2024

Departed: 04/14/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: Florence Ann Keathley entered into the presence of God surrounded by her loving family on Sunday, April 14, 2024 at her home in Brentwood, TN at the age of 81.Florence was born May 7, 1942 in Tacoma, WA to Philip Lawrence Paulsen and Elizabeth Helen(Schaler) Paulsen. One of her earliest memories is of the jubilation following VJ Day and the end ofWorld War II. She was raised in Portland, OR, where she was a doting big sister to younger siblings,Dale and Sharon. Upon graduation from Wilson High School, Florence attended Emanuel HospitalSchool of Nursing in Portland and received her RN license. Subsequently, she ventured cross country toWashington D.C., becoming a nurse at D.C. General Hospital. It was at church in her D.C. neighborhoodthat she met the love of her life, Phil Keathley, a naval officer from Wetumka, OK. Following their weddingand Phil's naval posting in Alameda, CA, they moved to Athens, GA where Phil earned his Ph.D. at theUniversity of Georgia and daughter, Laura, was born. They then established their home in California for38 years where they welcomed son, Craig. Florence became a full time homemaker and a loving andsupportive mother to her two children. Most recently, she and Phil lived 14 years in Tennessee wherethey celebrated 56 years of marriage.Florence accepted Jesus as her Lord and Savior as a child, and she served joyfully in her churchchildren's ministry as Sunday School and Wednesday night teacher for many years. She attended BibleStudy Fellowship for several decades, serving as a teacher in the children's department. For 15 yearsshe served as a counselor at Modesto Crisis Pregnancy Center helping single moms receive theeducation and resources necessary to successfully care for their babies.Florence's main hobby was service to church, community, and family. She loved to cook for her family,including big Sunday noon dinners. She loved to care for children including her 11 beloved grandchildren.She loved to plant flowers and beautify her yard. For many years, she canned quarts upon quarts of fruit,vegetables, pickles, relish, salsa, and laid up pints of various flavors of jam. Family was always hernumber one priority, and she loved people well.Florence is preceded in death by her parents, Philip and Elizabeth Paulsen and her in-laws, Luster andStella Keathley. She is survived by her husband Jackson Phillip Keathley of the home, daughter LauraBlomberg and son-in-law Sven, of Brentwood, TN, son Craig Keathley and daughter-in-law Krista ofElkton, MD, brother Dale Paulsen and sister-in-law Cecilia of Sherwood, OR, sister Sharon Hurley andbrother-in-law Mel of Turner, OR, brother-in-law James Keathley and sister-in-law Charlie Belle ofBenbrook, TX, sister-in-law Julia Keathley of Wetumka, OK, 11 grandchildren; Daniel, Jeremy, Jedidiah,John, Stella, Elsa, Annaliese, and Lucy Blomberg all of Brentwood, TN, and Devon, Carrie, and MelinaKeathley of Elkton, MD.Funeral service will be 10:00 am, Saturday, April 20, 2024 at Texas Banner Baptist Church of God, Wetumka, Oklahoma with Pastor Joe Lunsford officiating.Interment will follow at Larmar Cemetery.A Celebration of Life service will be held on May 11 in Nashville, TN.Services are under the direction of Hudson Phillips Funeral Home, Holdenville, Oklahoma.

Obituary Preview: Jewel Thomas "JT", "Scooter" Akin, born May 8th, 1920, passed away in Ada, Oklahoma on March 8th, 2024 at 103 years young.Jewel was born to Thomas "Bud" Akin and Carrie Bell (nee Nalley), on May 8th, 1920 in Sasakwa, Oklahoma in a cotton field; literally. Jewel loved to travel and lived in many places in his lifetime, including California and Colorado. He enjoyed hunting, fishing, fiddlin' and whittlin'. Jewel lived on his own and happily cooked his own meals until he moved into the nursing home this past winter. He was known for his specialty, chocolate gravy and biscuits.Jewel had a gentle, loving spirit. No matter where he went, he seemed to know someone. Bill T. Horn - May 05, 1934 - March 04, 2024

Departed: 03/04/2024 (Holdenville)

Obituary Preview: Bill T. Horn passed away Monday, March 4th, 2024 at Heritage Village Nursing Center in Holdenville, Oklahoma at the age of 89.Bill was born May 5, 1934 in Holdenville to William Thomas Horn and Lola E. (McCoy) Madden. He attended high school in River Bank, California. Bill married Jane Reid May 5, 1980. Bill joined the service at a very young age just prior to the Korean War. After leaving the service he became a journeyman lineman for the remainder of his career and retired from NEBF. Bill loved his horses and all horse related events. He was a member of the Calvin Roundup Club.Bill and Jane enjoyed square dancing and were members of the Boots and Bows Dance Club for several years. One of Bill's favorite things to do was having breakfast and playing rummy every morning with Jane and feeding Sadie breakfast under the table. He would always say "you two are my whole world!" Bill was preceded in death by his parents William Horn and Lola Madden, brothers; David Phillips (Sally), Lee Horn (Margaret), Bob Horn (Peggy), sister Shirley Crouse, and son Ronnie Horn.Survived by his beloved and devoted wife of 43 years Jane and his best little friend, his dog Sadie. Frequently Asked Questions

What is an obituary?

An obituary is a written notice that announces the death of a person, typically including their name, age, date of birth and death, and a brief biography. It's usually published in a newspaper, online obituary platform, or funeral home website to inform friends, family, and community members of the person's passing.

Why are obituaries important?

Obituaries serve as a way to honor and celebrate the life of the deceased, while also providing essential information to those who want to pay their respects. They help to notify people of the passing, share details about the funeral or memorial service, and offer a sense of closure for loved ones.

Who writes an obituary?

Typically, the family members or close friends of the deceased write the obituary. However, it can also be written by a funeral home or a professional obituary writer. In some cases, the deceased may have written their own obituary in advance.

What information should be included in an obituary?

A typical obituary includes the person's full name, age, date of birth and death, place of residence, occupation, education, hobbies, achievements, and surviving family members. It may also include information about the funeral or memorial service, charitable donations, and any other relevant details.

How long should an obituary be?

The length of an obituary can vary depending on the publication or platform. Generally, it should be concise and to the point, ranging from a few sentences to a short paragraph. Some online obituary platforms may allow for longer tributes or stories.

Can I include photos in an obituary?

Yes, many publications and online platforms allow you to include one or more photos with the obituary. This can be a great way to personalize the tribute and make it more meaningful.

How do I submit an obituary to a newspaper?

Contact the newspaper's obituary department directly to inquire about their submission process and deadlines. Be prepared to provide the necessary information and payment for publication.

Can I write my own obituary in advance?

Yes, some people choose to write their own obituary in advance as a way to take control of how they're remembered and to spare their loved ones from having to do it during a difficult time.

Is it necessary to include every detail about the person's life?

No, it's not necessary to include every detail about the person's life. Focus on sharing the most important and meaningful aspects of their life, personality, and accomplishments.

Can I include humor or personal anecdotes in an obituary?

Absolutely! Obituaries don't have to be somber and serious. Including humor or personal anecdotes can help capture the person's spirit and personality.

How do I handle sensitive or private information in an obituary?

Be respectful and considerate when sharing information about the deceased. Avoid including sensitive or private details that might be uncomfortable for family members or friends.

Can I include quotes or lyrics in an obituary?

Yes, quotes or lyrics that were meaningful to the deceased can be a beautiful way to add depth and personality to the obituary.

What if I need to make corrections to an already published obituary?

Contact the publication or platform where the obituary was published as soon as possible to request corrections. They may have specific procedures for making changes.

How long does it take for an obituary to be published?

The timeframe for publishing an obituary varies depending on the publication or platform. Newspapers typically have specific deadlines for submission and publication, while online platforms may publish immediately.

Can I republish an obituary on social media or other websites?

Check with the original publication or platform for permission before republishing an obituary on social media or other websites. Some may have copyright restrictions or requirements.

What is a death notice versus an obituary?

A death notice is a brief announcement of someone's passing, often including only basic information such as name, age, and date of death. An obituary is a more detailed tribute that celebrates the person's life and legacy.

Can I write an obituary for someone who has been deceased for a long time?

Yes, you can still write an obituary for someone who has been deceased for a long time. This can be a meaningful way to honor their memory and share their story with others.

How do I find old obituaries?

You can search online archives of newspapers or genealogy websites that specialize in collecting historical records. Local libraries or historical societies may also have archives of old newspapers and obituaries.

Can I use an obituary as part of a eulogy or memorial service?

Absolutely! An obituary can serve as a starting point for crafting a eulogy or memorial service that celebrates the person's life and legacy.

What is the difference between an obituary and a necrology?

A necrology is a list of people who have died within a certain timeframe or community, often without additional biographical information. An obituary is a more detailed tribute that celebrates an individual's life and legacy.

Can I include charitable donations or memorial funds in an obituary?

Yes, many families choose to include information about charitable donations or memorial funds in lieu of flowers. This can be a meaningful way to honor the deceased and support a worthy cause.

How do I handle multiple marriages or complex family relationships in an obituary?

Treat all family members with respect and sensitivity when writing an obituary. You may choose to list multiple spouses or partners separately, or focus on highlighting the person's relationships with their children, siblings, or other loved ones.

What if I'm unsure about what information to include in an obituary?

Draft several versions of the obituary and ask trusted family members or friends for feedback. You can also consult with a funeral home or professional writer for guidance.

Can I create my own custom design for an online obituary?

Many online platforms offer customizable templates and design options for creating unique and personalized tributes. You may also be able to upload your own images or graphics.

How long will an online obituary remain available?

This varies depending on the platform or website hosting the obituary. Some may keep them archived indefinitely, while others may remove them after a certain period of time.
